div.p:
sŕī gōyindapōṟēri manmaṟāḷu
kūjapōṟēri kuntuṞ lōkama
nilpina stānaṁbu
The gift endowed by Lōkama, daughter of ..japoṟēri, and grand-daughter of Śrī Goyindapoṟēri.
The place (stānaṁbu) (was) established by Lōkama, the daughter of (Kū)japōṟēru (and) grand-daughter of Gōyindapōṟēru.

It is not entirely clear whether the spelling kuntuṞ lōkama (56, line 2) represents a halanta ‹Ṟ› or presents a simplified visual representation of a compound character. Although there is no picture of the inscription in 56 the reading could be altered on the grounds of attested forms in other inscriptions. If the element gōyinda is a variant of skt. govinda the length of the ‹ō› is probable. The reading pōṟēri is due to 1) similar attestations and 2) the etymology. Because of the absence of a graphemic differentiation between /o/ and /ō/ the spelling is ambivalent. 1) The element appears as part of names in vasantipōṟi (23542 G), maṃkhipoṟṟiyāru (23942 I), and kūcapōṟiyāri, kūcapōṟiki (24442 K). Via Zvelebil’s rule the spelling poṟṟi indirectly points towards pōṟi as well. 2) The word pōṟi means ‘young’ (probably originally gender neutral) and corresponds to forms with long vowel in modern Telugu (like pōṟigāṃḍu ‘young man, boy’(534). The incomplete name -japōṟēri could perhaps be complemented as *kūjapōṟēri; confer 2448-942 K. The female donor’s name is lōkama with the suffix -ama, probably from amma ‘mother’. The inscription was found [o]n top of a niche containing a liṅgaA. R. No. 281 of 1922 . This niche is probably referred to by stānaṁbu. The inscription is one of the fewer that mention a woman as donor.
The “place” seems to be a niche with a lingam. The inscription is one of the comparatively few that refer to a female donor.

The inscription was noted in A. R. No. 281 of 1922 and first published by J. Ramayya Pantulu in 2056 with few metadata and without translation and picture. K. M. Sastri re-edited the inscription based on Ramayya Pantulu’s edition together with a translation in 283-2845.
